bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank F. Law, June 11, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Law for courtesies shown him during the Cornwell portrait unveiling. He informs Law that Kissinger has had a stroke and is not expected to live.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank F. Law, June 11, 1941
div1.opener:
June 11, 1941
Mr. Frank F. Law
1600 Arch Street
Philadelphia, Pa.
My dear Mr. Law:
div1.p:
May I express to you my appreciation for the many courtesies
which you and your colleagues showed to me in Cleveland. The whole affair
was very pleasant and stimulating.

I have just written Mr. Kellogg about the tragic aftermath which
affected Mr. Kissinger. While chatting in Cleveland, he told me that not
long ago he had a bad spell of something which affected his face. The
thought occurred to me that he might have had a mild stroke. At any rate,
I have received word from Mrs. Kissinger that he arrived home on Tuesday,
the day after the Cleveland meeting, feeling fine and very happy about
the whole affair. On Wednesday morning at nine o'clock he developed a
severe stroke and at the time Mrs. Kissinger wrote me, he was still uncon-
scious and not expected to live. I know you will be interested in this.
I hope to keep in touch with them and to know what happens.

Wasn't it fortunate indeed that Mr. Cornwell was able to make
the sketches of him when he did?

May I thank you again for the very flattering introduction which
you made of me? I look with considerable pleasure on my friendship with
you and your organization.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
